Project Description  The North East Community Restoration and Development (NECORD) 
Project  II  continues  the  government’s  rehabilitation  program  for  the 
conflict-affected  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces.  Post-
conflict rehabilitation will address basic needs in the conflict-affected 
areas  through  health,  education,  irrigation,  agriculture,  community 
development,  institutional  infrastructure,  and  income-generation 
subprojects.  
   
Rationale  In May 2009, the government defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil 
Eelam and gained full control of the Northern province. However, the 
conflict  displaced  more  than  290,000  people  from  districts  in  the 
Northern province. These internally displaced persons (IDPs), who were 
housed in 32 special welfare centers, were in addition to the more than 
150,000 people who were displaced before the renewed outbreak of 
fighting in 2006 and who are living with friends and relatives and in 
welfare centers in Jaffna, Mannar, and Vavuniya districts. About 65% of 
the recent IDPs living in welfare centers have been relocated to their 
original places of residence, or with host families (including friends and 
relatives) by the end of January 2010. The rest are expected to be 
resettled by about mid-2010 as demining progresses.  
 
  The government initiated a needs assessment in the second quarter of 
2009  by  interdepartmental  teams  from  the  central  and  provincial 
governments.  The  needs  assessment  identified  two  programs  for 
immediate rehabilitation and medium-term reconstruction: (i) the 180-
day  program,  and  (ii)  the  medium-term  (3  years)  rehabilitation  and

  Mines and unexploded ordinance are the main risks in the project areas. 
The government is coordinating with demining agencies to ensure that 
the areas where people are resettling, including subproject sites, are 
prioritized. District secretaries are responsible for coordinating demining 
at the ground level, and the executing agency is responsible at the

  Price  escalation  is  another  risk.  An  increase  in  the  demand  for

I.   THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
supplementary  loan  to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  North  East 
Community Restoration and Development Project (NECORD) II.1 
 
II.   THE APPROVED PROJECT 
 
A.   Project Rationale 
 
2.  Approved on 14 April 2005, NECORD II was designed to assist the Government of Sri 
Lanka with its rehabilitation program for the conflict-affected areas of the Northern and Eastern 
provinces. The project was processed concurrently with the Tsunami-Affected Areas Rebuilding 
Project2 to ensure that people affected by both the conflict and the December 2004 tsunami would 
benefit equally since they are in the same districts. Post-conflict rehabilitation seeks to address 
basic  needs  in  the  conflict-affected  areas  through  health,  education,  irrigation,  agriculture, 
community development, institutional infrastructure, and income-generation subprojects. 
 
B.   Objectives and Scope 
 
3.  The main objective of NECORD II is to help meet basic human needs and improve living 
conditions rapidly in conflict-affected areas of the Northern and Eastern provinces by restoring 
basic social infrastructure, community and public services, and livelihoods. NECORD II is also 
supporting  rehabilitation  and  relief  efforts  under  way  in  conflict-affected  areas.  Rehabilitation 
subprojects under NECORD II will further community development, rehabilitate access roads, 
develop institutional infrastructure, and restore basic infrastructure. Given the recent increase in 
construction activity in the Northern and Eastern provinces, an HIV/AIDS awareness campaign will 
be carried out for construction workers and internally displaced persons (IDPs). The project design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
C.   Original Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
4.  As shown in Appendix 2, NECORD II was financed by an Asian Development Fund (ADF) 
loan of SDR16.91 million ($26.0 million at the time of approval) together with an ADF grant of 
$14.0 million and a cofinancing grant from the Swedish International Development Cooperation 
Agency (Sida) of SKr40 million ($5.9 million). The government's contribution for taxes and duties is 
$9.1 million. The loan and grants became effective on 28 July 2005, and the closing date for 
NECORD II is currently 30 March 2010. 
 
D.   Status of and Progress in Project Implementation 
 
5.  NECORD II has performed satisfactorily in meeting its objectives. Between 2006 and May 
2009,  renewed  conflict  disrupted  the  project.  After  the  government  gained  full  control  of  the 
Eastern province in mid-2007, the working environment in its districts improved. The government 
introduced  a  180-day  program  to  rehabilitate  the  essential  basic  infrastructure  and  facilitate 
resettlement of IDPs in the Eastern province. Most IDPs in the province—about 150,000—were

6.  Following the resurgence of the conflict, the government imposed access and security 
restrictions in districts of the Northern province, mainly in Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu, in 2006. 
Subprojects have and are being implemented in parts of Jaffna, Mannar, and Vavuniya districts, 
where  there  is  access  and  no  security  restrictions.  Since  2008,  no  subprojects  involving 
reconstruction activities that require cement and steel (being bulk items and difficult to transport) 
have been approved in Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu districts, where the conflict was most severe. 
However, small community-based activities, such as training and reconstruction of village gravel 
roads, were undertaken under both NECORD II and other Asian Development Bank (ADB) projects 
to remain engaged with the people of the area. The project performance assessments as of 
November 2009 are in Appendix 3.  
 
7.  In May 2009, the government defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and gained full 
control of the Northern province.3 By the end of the war, about 290,000 IDPs from districts in the 
Northern province were housed in 32 special welfare centers in Jaffna, Mannar, and Vavuniya. An 
additional 150,000 IDPs who had been displaced before the outbreak of the 2006 conflict are still 
living with friends and relatives and in welfare centers in Jaffna, Mannar, Puttalam, and Vavuniya 
districts.  
 
8.  On 1 July 2009, the government launched a 180-day plan4 for emergency rehabilitation and 
reconstruction of public administration and provision of basic human needs related infrastructure 
and services to facilitate resettlement of IDPs and restart their livelihoods.By mid-January 2010, 
 
about 190,000 of the IDPs who had been housed in the Vavuniya welfare camps since May 2009 
had returned to their original places of residence or temporary transit centers closer to their original 
places of residence, or were staying with host families (including friends and relatives).5 This is 
broadly in line with the government target to resettle a majority of these people in their original 
places of residence by the end of January 2010. Returnees are engaging in reconstruction of their 
homes; cleaning the village access roads and common facilities such as wells and irrigation 
canals; and restarting livelihoods such as agriculture, fishing, small business, and trading. While 
about 100,000 IDPs remain in the main welfare centers, they have been able to move in and out of 
the centers for extended periods since 1 December 2009. These remaining IDPs are expected to 
be resettled in the first half of 2010, after land mines have been cleared.  
 
9.  To help meet basic human needs and the most urgent community and social infrastructure 
needs of the returning IDPs, as identified by the 180-day program, the government requested ADB 
and other development partners to (i) assist with restarting stalled projects in the conflict-affected 
areas, (ii) provide additional assistance through surplus funds and loan savings from the existing 
portfolio, and (iii) provide additional emergency financing. In response, NECORD II has supported 
the 180-day program, providing $1 million for the most urgently needed repairs to some of the 
damaged basic infrastructure such as schools, hospitals, and administrative facilities. In December 
2009, the Government of Australia through the Australian Agency for International Development 
(AusAID) provided grant cofinancing of A$8 million ($7.3 million) to NECORD II.6 This cofinancing

10.  Review missions in 2009 observed that some of the infrastructure built or rehabilitated by 
the government and its development partners since 2001 has been partially damaged. In most 
cases, the assets have not been destroyed and can be repaired quickly. Interdepartmental teams 
from  the  central  and  provincial  governments  conducted  needs  assessments  for  the  180-day 
program, as well as the medium-term (3 years) rehabilitation and development of the former 
conflict-affected areas, in the second quarter of 2009. The 180-day program is concentrating 
mainly on repairing the most urgently needed and partially damaged community infrastructure, 
while the medium-term program will focus on rebuilding the destroyed larger infrastructure needed 
to support medium- to longer-term development and livelihood needs. Appendix 4 summarizes the 
medium-term  requirement  based  on  the  needs  assessment.  An  estimated  $2,680  million  is 
required to meet the medium-term requirements. The main sectors that require support include 
housing  (more  than  $317  million);  power  ($152  million);  roads  ($949 million);  transport  ($238 
million); agriculture, fisheries, and livestock (more than $186 million); and education (more than 
$90 million).  
  
11.  As of 31 December 2009, $25.88 million (99.95%) of the original ADF loan component had 
been committed. The ADF grant and the Sida grant had been fully committed. The disbursements 
were as follows: $22.47 million (86.77%) for the ADF loan, $13.06 million (93.3%) for the ADF 
grant, and $4.77 million (82.2%) for the Sida grant. Of the 593 subprojects identified, more than 
500 subprojects were completed and handed over to the beneficiaries. The rest of the subprojects 
are progressing satisfactorily and will be completed by March 2010 (the current loan closing date).  
 
12.  NECORD II is complying with key project covenants, as detailed in Appendix 5. One key 
covenant includes filling vacancies, especially in the education and health sectors where NECORD 
II had the most subprojects. Based on the observations during recent ADB review missions, 
teachers  and  medical  staff  vacancies  are  being  filled  in  all  the  rural  facilities  created  under 
NECORD  II.  Specific  subprojects  have  been  included  in  the  ongoing  loan  to  train  staff  in 
anticipation of the future requirements.  
 
III.   THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE

14.  Through  this  proposed  supplementary  loan  to  NECORD  II,  ADB  will  support  the

provide a quick, effective, and efficient way to meet essential needs and deliver services to 
returning IDPs using the proposed additional funds.  
 
B.   Impact on the Project 
 
15.  The proposed supplementary financing will directly benefit the returning IDPs and host 
communities,  and  assist  in  rehabilitating,  reconstructing,  and  developing  areas  affected  by 
decades of conflict. The project design incorporates opportunities to enhance participation of the 
local community and local staff in decision making, and aims to build local capacity. Equity and 
conflict sensitivity will be pursued through (i) the selection of subprojects that ensure an ethnic 
balance,  reflecting  the  ethnic  composition  of  the  affected  areas;  (ii)  geographical  balance; 
(iii) consultation  with  affected  stakeholders  regarding  the  final  choice  of  subprojects;  and 
(iv) livelihood recovery activities that are undertaken close to the affected populations, with their 
active involvement as stakeholders in the process. Details of the proposed sector scope and 
selection criteria, including the estimated costs, are in Appendix 7. The expanded scope of the 
NECORD II will enhance the project’s impact, outcome, and outputs. The revised design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 8. Appendix 9 provides details of the grievance and dispute 
prevention and settlement mechanisms designed to minimize tensions between communities.  
 
C.   Rationale 
 
16.  Since the conflict ended in 2009, ADB has worked with the government to find ways to 
support urgent rehabilitation through ongoing projects in the conflict-affected areas. These projects 
include (i) NECORD II (repairing damaged schools, hospitals, and administrative buildings; and 
providing farm tractors to farmers societies to restart agriculture); (ii) the Conflict-Affected Areas 
Rebuilding Project9 (expediting the ongoing road works in Northern province and purchasing a 
motor  launch  to  connect  the  islands  of  Jaffna  district  with  Jaffna  peninsula;  and  restarting 
installation  of  medium-voltage  and  rural  electrification  schemes,  especially  in  Kilinochchi  and

framework  in  line  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  is  in  Appendix  10.12 Most  of  the

infrastructure. All subproject proposals have been reviewed against the checklist developed for

subproject for approval to the provincial project coordination committee. Where necessary, the 
PMU requests additional information before the subproject is approved for implementation. Since

21.  The  executing  agency  for  the  project  is  the  Ministry  of  Nation  Building  and  Estate

established effective implementation mechanisms in all districts in Northern province, enabling 
speedy implementation and results. Therefore, the implementation arrangements and structure will 
not be changed, except that additional engineers will be included to ensure quality and further 
expedite the implementation of the subprojects (Appendix 13).The approval of subprojects will 
follow the transparent process adopted under the ongoing loans and grants implemented in the 
conflict-affected areas, and subprojects will be approved by the provincial project coordinating 
committee as in the original loan. Ground-level coordination through the government agent and by 
the ADB Sri Lanka Resident Mission with other multilateral and bilateral development partners will 
ensure activities and approaches are complementary.

construction industry, especially the contractors in Northern and Eastern provinces. The use of

the government requests the use of state-owned enterprises to repair some of the damaged 
community infrastructure (as done under government's 180-day program explained in para. 8), 
staff will review the requests on a case-by-case basis. Where justified in accordance with ADB's

IV.   PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
 
29.  In the conflict-affected Northern and Eastern provinces, poverty levels are estimated to be 
about 37%—much higher than in the rest of the country, although there are gaps in government 
surveys  for  much  of  the  area.  Basic  socioeconomic  facilities  need  to  be  restored  if  affected 
communities are to recover and return to normalcy. An updated summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 15.  
 
30.  NECORD II will address the urgent needs of about 1.5 million people, including a significant 
number  of  physically  disabled  people,  households  headed  by  women,  and  children.  Of  this 
population,  about  290,000  people  who  were  in  welfare  centers  for  much  of  2009  are  being 
resettled  in  their  original  places  of  residence.  By  restoring  essential  community  and  social 
infrastructure and services, as well as agriculture and fisheries sectors that form the backbone of 
the economy in the affected areas, NECORD II will help to rebuild affected communities and to 
stabilize the economic base of local populations, helping people to move from dependence on 
government support to sustainable livelihoods.  
 
31.   NECORD II focuses on restoring preexisting facilities, allowing for technical improvements 
and future demand, based on a least-cost approach. Taking into consideration the many years of 
neglect, project interventions focus not only on the physical rehabilitation of damaged infrastructure 
but also on the restoration of the physical and institutional arrangements for legal, administrative, 
and technical services.  
 
32.  Creating  an  environment  that  is  conducive  to  the  participation  of  vulnerable  and 
marginalized groups in the conflict-affected areas in reconstruction activities is an urgent need. 
War widows, households headed by women, single parent families and single women with elderly 
dependents have to deal with transformations in social roles that place new burdens on them. The 
project  will  help  them  to  reestablish  local  community  organizations  and  provide  them  with 
livelihood-related  skills  training,  access  to  credit  and  extension  services  and  necessary 
administrative and legal services. This will enable them to become economically independent, 
improve the well-being of their families and in the longer term will reduce existing inequalities, 
discrimination and marginalization. An updated gender action plan is in Appendix 16. 
 
B.  Assumptions, Risks, and Mitigation Measures 
 
33.  The  project  incorporates  a  number  of  safeguards  to  improve  and  strengthen  the 
governance and institutional capacity of the executing agency, implementing agencies, and the 
PMU. The assessment of ongoing projects indicates that the risks have been well managed. 
Coordination and monitoring by the ADB Sri Lanka Resident Mission further strengthened the 
process.  
 
34.  Risks. Price escalation is one of the main risks. An increase in the demand for construction 
materials, which are already in short supply, could drive up prices and affect the amount of 
reconstruction that can be carried out in the area. Based on the lessons after the 2004 tsunami, 
ADB has highlighted the issue with the government. To minimize the risk, studies are under way to

10 
identify adequate sites for supply of construction materials, and to obtain all necessary statutory 
permits  to  facilitate  the  construction  industry.  Contracts  will  be  closely  monitored  for  price 
variations.   
 
35.  Demining. Complete demining of the area will still take some time. In addition to the 
security forces, eight agencies are assisting the government in demining. The Ministry of Nation 
Building is coordinating the activities of these agencies at the national level, while government 
agents  or  district secretaries  are  facilitating  at  the  ground  level.  Some  development  partners 
(mainly the United Nations and bilateral agencies) are also supporting this effort. Clearing village 
areas and farmland to enable the prompt return of IDPs is the priority. 
 
V.   ASSURANCES 
 
36.  The government has given the following assurances, relevant to NECORD II, in addition to 
the standard assurances. These will be incorporated into the legal documents.  
 
(i)  Continuity  and  integration.  The  government  will  ensure  the  continuity  of  the 
implementation of the work financed under the original NECORD II and the work 
financed under the supplementary finance. 
 
(ii)  Government administration. The project management arrangements reflect the 
present  government  administrative  structure  that  may  change  during 
implementation.  The  government  will  immediately  notify  ADB  of  any  proposed 
change  in  the  administrative  structure  in  the  project  areas,  and  take  all  steps 
necessary to ensure that the project management arrangements are revised in 
consultation with ADB to reflect the new administrative structure and protect the 
viability of the project. The government will take all steps necessary and within its 
power to ensure that any successor project management entities enter into such 
project agreements, or other agreements with ADB, as ADB may request.  
 
(iii)  Peace building and community reconciliation. The government will ensure that 
all conflict-related project interventions contribute to peace building and community 
reconciliation. If any proposed subproject or intervention has an actual or threatened 
negative impact on peace building and community reconciliation, the government 
agrees that ADB shall be entitled to determine whether such intervention should be 
continued, redesigned, suspended, or canceled.  
 
(iv)  Access. The government will ensure that staff, consultants, materials, vehicles, 
equipment,  and  other  items  required  for  project  implementation  will  be  given 
reasonable access to project areas.  
 
(v)  Operation  and  maintenance.  The  government  will  ensure,  and  will  cause  the 
executing agency and implementing agencies to ensure, that the project facilities 
are operated and maintained, and that adequate budgetary and other resources are 
provided for this purpose. The government will also ensure that community-based 
organizations charged with operating and maintaining facilities provided under both 
projects are provided with the necessary support and training to undertake such 
activities.  
 
(vi)  Subproject selection. The government and each implementing agency will ensure 
that all subprojects meet to ADB’s satisfaction, the agreed selection criteria and

11
other  implementation  arrangements,  and  that  subprojects  are  controlled  and 
monitored to ADB’s satisfaction. 
 
(vii)  Governance  and  anticorruption. The government and ADB agree to adopt a 
policy of zero-tolerance of corruption in relation to assistance provided under the 
project(s), and by development partners. The government will take measures to 
quickly  sanction  private  individuals,  entities,  or  public  officials  who  actually  or 
attempt to take advantage of donor funds, or the loss of documents, such as the 
absence of property title documents, court records, or bank accounts.  
 
(viii)  Statement of expenditures audit. The government agrees to ensure that ADB staff 
members are granted access to key books and records in order to complete a 
statement of expenditures audit within 6 months of effectiveness.  
 
(ix)  Post-completion audit. The government will ensure that a special post-completion 
performance audit is conducted in accordance with ADB’s disaster and emergency 
policy to consider governance, transparency, and financial accountability.  
 
(x)  ADB monitoring and compliance. The government will allow and facilitate ADB’s 
representatives to conduct spot and random checks on (a) flow of funds through the 
imprest  account,  each  second-generation  imprest  account,  and  each  third-
generation imprest account, and their use for the project in accordance with the 
financing agreement; (b) work in progress; and (c) project implementation. 
 
(xi)  Participation. The government will ensure, or will cause each executing agency or 
implementing  agency  to  ensure,  that  community-based  organizations, 
nongovernment  organizations,  and  beneficiaries  are  involved  in  subproject 
selection, design, implementation, and monitoring.  
 
37.  The execution of a project agreement in a form satisfactory to ADB is a condition to loan 
effectiveness.  ADB will require a project agreement in a form substantially the same as that 
agreed under the original NECORD II project.

subprojects will cover the reconstruction of partly and fully damaged basic social infrastructure, 
expansion  of  rural  electrification,  and  restarting  livelihoods.  Emphasis  will  be  given  to 
reestablishing the civil administration, basic health care, schools, rural electrification schemes, 
minor access roads, minor irrigation, community water supply, and vocational and skills training

3.  Health.  Subprojects  will  restore  critical  referral  medical  facilities  through  hospital 
reconstruction  and  refurbishment,  provision  and  replacement  of  medical  equipment  and

health  clinics.  Although  hospital  staffing  is  generally  satisfactory,  an  essential  subproject 
selection  criterion  will  stipulate  the  availability  of  sufficient  qualified  staff  to  operate  the

Trincomalee hospital are being used for urgent works under the 180-day program in selected

unavailable; and (iii) provision of training to teachers in special subjects, such as primary,

destroyed. Specialist training will be provided to improve the quality of the teachers, especially 
new recruits.

PROJECT-SPECIFIC GRIEVANCE PREVENTION AND RESOLUTION  
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The project-specific grievance prevention and resolution analysis intends to contribute to 
enhancing the capability of the North East Community Restoration and Development Project 
(NECORD) II to address potential project-related conflict and grievances arising during design 
and implementation. This appendix (i) examines the sources and consequences of conflict, (ii) 
determines  the  factors  that  can  be  addressed  or  prevented  through  NECORD  II,  and  (iii) 
determines how to strengthen resilience through development assistance.  
 
B.   Setting 
 
2.  Northern province has an area of 8,884 square kilometers, covering 14% of the total 
landmass of Sri Lanka. This includes 6.6% (594 square kilometers) of inland waters and about 
54% of forest coverage (4,797 square kilometers). Based on the 1981 census, the province had 
an estimated population of more than 1.1 million, of which nearly 86% are Sri Lankan Tamils, 
3% Sinhalese, 6% Tamils of Indian origin, and 5% Muslims. Before the conflict, the province 
accounted for a significant share of the gross domestic product (GDP) through agricultural 
products such as paddy, vegetables, livestock, and fruits. It also had small-scale industries such 
as light manufacturing and textiles. Further, the province had significant potential to increase the 
export-oriented industries based on its rich natural resources. However, Northern province 
contributed only 2.9% of GDP in 2007—the lowest regional share. 
 
B.  Conflict Prevention and Resolution Analysis 
 
3.  NECORD II responds to the needs of the IDPs from all ethnic groups in the Northern 
province. During the preparation of the supplementary financing, discussions were held with 
provincial and district officials (where possible), as well as central government officials, to 
ensure  ownership  of  the  project  and  its  outputs.  Given  that  the  resettlement  process  is 
underway and many IDPs have recently started to return to their original home areas, it was not 
possible to undertake consultations with the returning IDPs themselves. However, consultations 
will be done during subproject design and implementation once communities have begun to be 
reestablished.  The supplementary financing is designed to ensure that the outcomes are 
shared equitably among ethnic groups and across the entire target areas. NECORD II is not 
expected to contribute to any intensification of social tensions. Based on lessons derived from 
implementing ADB-funded projects in conflict-affected areas, the implementing agencies should 
continue to explain the objectives to local political and other community leaders to gain their 
endorsement and acceptance.  
 
4.  As noticed in the ongoing projects in the conflict-affected areas, a large percentage of 
the  contracts  based  on  competitive  bidding  are  being  undertaken  by  contractors  from  the 
districts. The same trend is expected with the proposed supplementary loan. Similarly, local 
labor is seen to benefit from the subprojects in these areas. Local labor will not only earn 
livelihoods from jobs created by the subprojects, but also gain skills that will make the workers 
more employable in the long term all around the country.  
 
5.  In  the  current  post  conflict-situation,  some  security  restrictions  will  continue.  The 
implementing agencies, as in the ongoing projects in these areas, will coordinate and facilitate 
implementation of subprojects without undue delay. All contractors are expected to adhere to 
the security procedures in place. During the initial phases of implementation, subprojects are

A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis, describes how the 
project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy of the 
partner country. 
 
Sri Lanka's poverty reduction strategy is included in the 10-year development framework (10YDF) 2006–2016, Mahinda 
Chintana. ADB's country partnership strategy (CPS) 2009–2011 for Sri Lanka, approved in 2008, is aligned to the framework 
and the program for the next 3 years is focused on the government's priority areas. ADB’s strategy focuses on the two pillars 
identified  in  the  framework.  These  are  (i)  strengthening  the  investment  climate,  and  (ii)  achieving  socially  inclusive 
development.  The  first  pillar  deals  with  infrastructure  development  and  human  resource  development  to  improve 
competitiveness.  The  second  pillar  focuses  on  regional  disparities  and  looks  at  development  of  infrastructure  and 
administrative and absorptive capacity in the poorer regions to improve the delivery of public services.    
 
Comprehensive poverty data is not available for Northern and Eastern provinces. However, poverty in the former conflict 
areas is significant, with government figures indicating the poverty incidence at around 37%, well over twice the national 
average but still likely to be an underestimate. Destruction of assets and infrastructure, displacement, loss of life and 
livelihood, and destruction of the social fabric characterize the poverty situation in these areas, setting it apart from rest of the 
country. The 10-year development framework has a separate chapter on the conflict-affected areas and states that the current 
policies are designed to protect and resettle displaced communities and to reconstruct the economic and physical and social 
infrastructure with the aim of assuring sustained long-term development of Northern and Eastern provinces. With the ending 
of military operations in May 2009, reconstruction and development of the former conflict areas has become a priority for the 
government. In May 2009 the government formulated a development plan for Northern province, similar to the one developed 
for Eastern provinces as the government gained full control of that province. This is a 3-year plan, which looks at the same 
issues discussed in the Mahinda Chintana. 
  
Through this proposed supplementary loan to NECORD II, ADB will support the government's efforts to meet basic human 
needs, particularly of the returning IDPs, and assist them in restarting their livelihood activities through the reconstruction of 
essential community and social infrastructure damaged by the conflict. The emphasis will be on helping to reestablish the civil 
administration, basic health care and education services as well as support for rural electrification schemes, minor access 
roads, minor irrigation, community water supply, and vocational and skills training for livelihood development.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka: 
The civil conflict over 3 decades has severely affected the communities in these areas. Loss of life, livelihoods, incomes, and 
property  has  resulted  in  significant  socioeconomic  and  psychological  stress.  In  the  conflict-affected  areas,  essential 
investments have not been made for a long time. 
 
The project will meet basic human needs by reestablishing vital services such as fisheries and irrigation infrastructure, health 
and educational facilities, water supply, agricultural support services, and institutions to revive economic activities. This will 
lead to employment, income generation, rehabilitation of displaced persons, and restoration of social stability in these areas.  
 
Improvement of services and infrastructure will also encourage people to return to their original villages and settlements. With 
this end in view, the project will strengthen health and educational facilities, while bolstering local institutions. Community-
based organizations will be established and supported, saving will be encouraged, women will be made more self-reliant, 
microcredit will be introduced, and recreational facilities will be provided.  
                               
In Northern and Eastern provinces, the people affected by the conflict are especially vulnerable because of gender, age, 
disability, and general breakdown in their traditional livelihood systems. Internally displaced persons who wish to return to 
their areas of origin need support in reestablishing their homes and their livelihoods. Essential services such as schools, 
hospitals, clinics, water, and power supply are lacking in these areas. The neglect of minor irrigation schemes has constrained 
agricultural production. Onetime surplus food production areas have become food-deficit areas. Livestock numbers have

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
The beneficiaries of the project are a war-affected population that had suffered loss of family members, displacement, loss of 
property, lack of access to essential social services, and long years of violence and insecurity. Income levels and human 
development indicators for these areas are among the gravest in Sri Lanka. The conflict and lack of security were the principal 
cause for poverty and the most binding constraint to poverty reduction and economic development. Poverty in these areas is 
due to war-related destruction of property and life, which has set back these regions from where they were prior to the war, 
and lack of development over the last 30 years. Restrictions on movement of people and taking over of property by parties to 
the war have interrupted traditional livelihoods including in agriculture and fisheries. The needs of these communities are 
manifold. It consists of rebuilding and restoration of infrastructure and systems, establishing community life in certain areas, 
provision of basic social services, and connecting these regions with the rest of the country.
